reviewText:
Good game!

I've played Happy Wars for two years on Xbox Live, and now it has arrived on Steam.

The game is simple.
Endless matches. A war between two castles. Three classes (Warrior, Cleric and Mage). Leveling up characters and equipments. Building respawn towers. Having fun.
The graphics are kind of childish and the game is light, and that's good. It's a game for all ages.

There isn't much to tell about the game. It's as simple as it looks like, and it's incredibly enjoyable.

The main mode is the multiplayer mode. There is PvP for at least 6 players (up to 30), and there is the Co-Op mode (playing against bots) for at least 8 players.

There is also the single-player mode, with story mode, tutorials and the skirmish mode (the same as multiplayer, but only with bots).

The game is the same, but a PC port brings new possibilities.

Besides being able to play it using keyboard+mouse and also using a gamepad, adding players is way faster than on Xbox, and having a faster text chat helps a lot.

This game is not a pay-to-win. You're not forced to play against high-leveled people, and they won't charge you for accessing any part of the game. But of course there is some cool stuff you can get by using real money, such as better chances of getting good equipments, using it to improve equipments instead of using game money, unlocking the evolved classes faster and buying items.

That's one of my favorite free-to-play games, I'd recommend this to anyone who likes RPG, war games, magic games or even MOBA.

Play it! It's free! Have nice fun!

As much as I want to love this game(believe me, I do), I really can't recommend this game to anyone because of the atrocious matchmaking and rather repetetive gameplay/modes. It is a mediocre port locked at 30fps. There is no communication in lobbies or in matches, except for the small commands in matches, which do not really matter at all because they are constantly spammed, making them serve barely any purpose at all.

The visual style is both charming and gorgeous, and the gameplay is fun and addicting, but it is all the other negative factors that pulls my verdict for the game down.

There are no official servers or support for community servers, the game is 100% peer to peer. You are often tossed in matches with people from the other side of the globe, then kicked out in the middle of the match because either  A. The match was ended because there are too few players to actually countinue(everyone else has been disconnected), or B. You have lost connection to the other peers.

Certain items are pay2win only, but most of the items are available through luck and grinding, as expected for a f2p title. reviewText:
Early Access Review

OVERVIEW

Happy Wars is originally an Xbox Live exclusive games and now being ported to the PC. This game is a mixture of third person hack & slash with some little MOBA element into it. Is it a really good game ? Let see.

GAMEPLAY : 9/10

The game support total of 30 player with 15 on each side making it a chotic battle. This game is basically a tower defense type of game.

You have three class you can choose. A Warrior,Cleric & Mage. They also have an advanced class which is Berserker,Engineer & Zephyr Each of them have their own unique spells & skills. You even able to customize your own character by choosing a bunch of presets ( it doesn't provide a deep customization but at least it there )

The tutorial present to you is fairly well done explaining most of the basic & advanced things you need to know about the game mechanics.

You able to build a bunch of artillery to help defend your castle. Tower are also scattered throughout the area. Build them and you can respawn from over there without you having to walk from your castle to your enemy territory.

As you level up,you gain different type of skills and spells for you to choose. Sometimes it randomly give you a spell that you don't frequently use.

As far as i know there is no chat system,you only able to use command key.

You are not able to rebind your key either so that a troublesome for those who don't like the default key.

GRAPHICS : 9/10

The cartoony artsyle and visual appeal to me a lot.

There is a lot of colorful background and environment especially the coral stage where you can see bunch of fish swimming around.

Character models felt bland but it acceptable nonetheless.

Interface is neatly done as well as some of the particle.

Each stages just look amazing,offering different variety of environment and background.

AUDIO : 9.5/10

Sound effects wise.....is very good and those cute chibi voice that your character makes i find it pretty funny.

However the strongest point is the soundtrack.

Even though there is only 9 soundtrack in the game,all of it are phenomenal. Most of the stages have orchestral theme in it.

You can try listen at here : https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL5aE2-NvNJXOpOsTJCO3WfOepGjAgtXmR

LONG-LASTING APPEAL : 9/10

Doing chaotic battles never get old especially this game provide a lot of content. You able to upgrade and buff your equipment. You able to gain rewards too as you finish each battle.

There is a Heavy Spinner mode where you place 3 maximum bets on the items you want ( each bets cost 300 stars,placing more bets giving you higher chance to earn random items ). If you lucky you can earn rare items.

There is Happy Cards mode where you use 18 happy tickets ( which you can purchase using real cash ) to gain 2 common items and 1 premium items. If you are super lucky you can get super premium items !!!

The game provide Mission mode too,it basically a task which you must complete in order to earn different type of rewards. As you finish the mission that you are given,new mission are present to you.

Skrimish mode is extremely fun and never get old.

Multiplayer mode is also fun to play with online player. Though you can't communicate,the commands button is a nice touch at least. The matchmaking is not really that good either since you can paired up with players that have ten times way better equipment than you.

FINAL VERDICT : 9.1/10

I highly recommend you check this game out especially to those who like tower defense game.

This game offer different type of gameplay mechanics that many tower defense doesn't and it fresh to see something new. It an absolute blast to play even if you play by yourself. Updates is also constant which always introduced new content and fix some major bugs.

GRADE : A ( Excellent )

reviewText:
A simple, light-hearted and fun class-based MMO. Wow I'm already out of words here have some bullets

The Good

* Team-based gameplay ensures the fact that players need to rely on each other to win. Your teammates watch your back, heal it if necessary and are all but essential in pushing towards the enemy castle. You might have the best gear, but getting ganged up on by 4 people while you're all alone spells your death.

* A large assortment of gear ensures variety within builds. You might get the same item twice, and that's fine because there's a lot of things you can do with them besides let them collect dust. Transfer buffs, sell it for cash, use it as level-up material, the entire system is pretty smooth and effective. That, and beating people to death with magic flowers always warms the heart.

* Daily log-in rewards ensure that the player isn't always completely broke. Everyday you get some pocket change to use for various item modification purposes (or the spinner if you have a gambling problem) and after a while, a premium item. Pretty generous deal for just opening up the game.

* Its actually free to play. It's completely possible to find powerful gear just by playing the game, and I only bought a DLC pack to have some auxiliary weapons and armor. The kicker? Some of the stuff I already had was stronger than it. Ho ho, take that Mabinogi and Maple Story and shove it back into the cellar, troglodyte.

The Bad

* The game is a bit of a grindfest. Want to equip powerful items? Need to keep ranking up to increase your weight capacity. Want to unlock story missions? Need to keep ranking up. Want to find better stuff that isn't a twig with a smiley face? Rank. Up.

* Matchmaking is a bit shoddy. Sometimes, you'll be matched up with people weaker or on par with you. Alrighty then, fair game. Other times? Say hello to that player with an axe made of tears and fire, with more buffs than your fingers can count. All they need to do is BREATHE on you and you'll be atomically rearranged. This is really the most glaring issue of the game so far, and it is NOT helped by the small playerbase.

* Lag. The game runs smoothly most of the time, but sooner or later you'll find that one guy who won't die, lag teleports and still hits you. How bad could it get? The towers and timer stopped functioning in a round I had once, stuck on zero with no way to gain or lose tower control. After a random and chaotic few minutes, the round ended.

* You spend an uncomfortably long amount of time looking at the stats page after a round. This is a minor gripe, but what am I going to do with 30 seconds and nothing but TABLES.


Overall, this game is good. The positives outweigh the negatives immensely, and the game is free. Free. And easy to pick up. Go ahead, bolster the playerbase. See if I care

reviewText:
It's really rare for me to like or enjoy many PvP games, especially from the frustration of COD: Advanced Warfare, Halo 4, Titanfall, and even Street Fighter X Tekken. I think this might be one of the few games that I've really enjoyed fighting with a team, and not caring either winning or losing. It's entertaining in a playful way, as it looks silly as all hell.

I'm not going to lie, I ended up being discouraged with alot of games people recommend for me, TF2 being one of them. And Happy Wars, being a personally fun game, really makes me enjoy battling with others, because I feel like I'm actually improving, skillwise, and stat-wise. It's a little monotinous, but it's quite satisfying and relaxing, and very comically funny.

Most enjoyable part, is that it actually feels like I'm GETTING SOMEWHERE, if I keep playing! It randomly gives you weapons and armor, regardless of whether you're good or bad, and get even better equipment if you do better within the match yourself! K/D ratio? Nah, none of that, just do good overall. And like most Rpg games, you can upgrade your equipment to make them more useful in battle. And it's not randomly determined whether you get an item or not, only what sort of item that you get. So it's not pure RNG oriented. Of course if you like splurging, you can buy better stuff. Not that it's really needed in this game, really. It's simply an option, and not coercion.

However, it isn't fleshed out that much, and the amount of maps to play in are a bit....limited, I'll admit. It looks far too silly for anyone that wants a challenge, and for that, I think that's fine. More of a chance for it to being a special gem for those that are interested. The Lottery Wheel itself, is just pretty much a gamble with your happy stars for equipment, but you'll more than likely get something useful. If not, it has it's uses in another field, so don't be too quick to get rid of it. Match-making isn't all that great either, but at least it's able to rank players appropriately, based on how much they play, or how high their level is. So if you know there's someone that's been on it for years, and pretty much knows everything you don't, you can back out before the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ commences. And that's always a plus in my book.

(What? Ain't no-one paying me to go above and beyond in a video-game. Only in Tournaments, which is why I stick to fighting games for that.)

This is just my two cents in this game, and there's alot more, but I'm not inclined that much to actually give you too much. You got a brain. Decide for yourself if you want to try it. All I can do is give you is suggest.

One of the best massive warfare type games I have ever played.


The combat is very accessible for new players and can involve a lot of skill later on for higher level players. One on one battles are incredibly tense with both players utilizing unique skills (dependent on class), traps, and the environment to get the edge on your opponent. All of the skills feel very well balanced and I rarely feel like I lost and encounter because of a cheap move. The maps are the perfect size to keep the action flowing. Alternate paths add a layer of strategy to the game which I was not expecting, there is nothing better than being in the last minute of a game losing two towers to one and sneaking behind for the cheeky victory. A problem with this however is that a team of people partying together can easily stomp on un-organised teams (although this might be an advantage depending on the amount of friends you have). I have seen many complaining about the pay to play/play to win aspects of this game although in my time playing completely f2p I have only experienced a couple of sessions where people would destroying my entire team due to bought equipment, although these people where very high level with 80+ hours of play time. Getting decent equipment is not difficult and if you focus on the mission mode you should have good enough equipment to stay competitive with players with full premium gear. You may even find yourself besting p2ps easily if you are more strategic with your item modifications.

Overall happy wars is a fantastically designed game which doesn’t need fancy graphics to be incredibly enjoyable no matter what you skill level. reviewText:
I had logged many hours on this game on the Xbox 360 version, and recently started playing again on PC, using my Xbox One controller.

The game is MUCH better when played with a controller. With that being said, it is possible to get by without one - as I did for the first week or so of playing.

Pros:
- Simple gameplay that anyone can grasp the basics of in a short amount of time.
- Balance of classes is very good. There is no truly dominant class.
- Despite the basics of the game being easy to grasp, there is much room for more experienced players to play at a higher level strategically.
- You can beat people with better gear than you. Even players who spend $$$ don't always know how to use it.
- Teamwork is encouraged, and playing with friends will be advantageous and fun.
- Frequent events and log-in prizes keep up replay value.
- Good matchmaking system means games are  usually  even and fair.

- Ultimately, the game is pay-to-win, and there are some players who are almost unstoppable given their gear. These people are rare however, and shouldn't be encountered at lower levels. Some experienced players (myself included) will 'go easy' on beginners as to not discourage them from sticking with the game. Others will take advantage of new players and kill them mercilessly...
- LAG! For some reason in this game, when someone is laggy they become near invincible. Unusual, but frustrating.


Overall a very casual yet competitive game. You can play as seriously as you want. Co-op mode is great to learn the game mechanics against bots, who come in varying difficulties. You may also make a few friends in here, who you can then play with against real players.

Give it a go, its free after all :)))))))))

reviewText:
Family friendly free to play moba; its like the Wizard101 for mobas.

Happy Wars is a sort-of MOBA but doesn’t fully embrace what defines the genre. There’s no creep here, replaced instead by a straight head-to-head 8 to 15-player teams constantly spawning and running into battle. Towers also function rather differently. Instead of actively trying to destroy any towers in their path players are working to build their own, where they can then spawn. Spawning ever closer via towers and/or going straight to the enemies base are both valid strategies.

But perhaps the biggest change is the simplification of classes. With each respawn, you’ll choose between one of three: The melee-focused Warrior, the healing and support Cleric, and the ranged damage Mage. Each class is fairly simple to play with excellent tutorials for each.

It speaks to a pleasure as primal as that found in other online mobas even if it's more overtly juvenile: this isn't about bloodlust as such and it's only nominally about a sense of conquest. Predominantly Happy Wars is all about camaraderie like that found in say Mount and Blade or Splatoon.

Voice chat remains off the cards - an omission that's understandable given the desire to provide a safe space to play. The Menu UI is a little in your face with pop-ups galore but its worth pushing through. Its also free-to-play which is great because of how accessible this makes it with little to no monetary investment.

Happy Wars is a machine for happiness where each element, charm, genuinely funny and cute tone has been engineered to elicit a smile holding fun at a premium.

reviewText:
This game is fairly decent, especially on the Steam release.

In my opinion, at least, this version I see better. It may be downgraded, sure, but in reality, after playing this version for a while, I really don't see shelling out $60/yr just to play this game. Sure, there are other great titles on the Xbox, but most also have an emphasis on multiplayer. Since becoming a regular on the PC gaming community, I have seen the $60 for XBLG as not worth an investment.

In terms of gameplay, it is relatively unchanged. Despite coming from a downgraded version of the Xbox release, the same formula carries on from the Xbox version, but with it, the same flaws. One major flaw is the lack of alternative gamemodes. The developers would at least have done their best to incorporate a basic free-for-all/team deathmatch gamemode (which everybody knows everybody likes).

Another major flaw is that some of the elements in this game indeed work on paper, but in practical terms, there are elements that stand out from the rest.  These elements can bias gameplay toward certain play styles, but again, on matches with the ideal amount of participants, things like this make little to no difference.

Diving in to game-specific details, the primary objective is to siege the enemy's fort before the enemy does the like to you. You have two general options in this case: a full-scale rush, or a stealth trial. Stealth, however, is a bit of a mess. Even if you happen to get lucky from the skilled players not knowing you are behind enemy lines (or even the rest of the conditions are in your favor), the AI are self-conscious and can easily tell you are in their grounds. Despite this, the AI are relatively weak and are pretty easy to kill. But especially with lack of communication (even in this version) and an inability to fully hide yourself, it makes stealth almost a non-option. There are times where players have succeeded in such a risk, but again, these kinds of stuff are more luck-based than skill-based.

Overall, besides the many execution failures in this game, this game is nevertheless a good experience. For those who have the Xbox version, it is indeed a worthwhile move to get this version and try it out. But accounting for the minor and little number of major flaws this game has, I wouldn't necessarily recommend this game to respect those who would rant from me, but at the same time, I woudn't say this is something to stay away from. However, because Steam requires it, my final score is the only deciding factor in my recommendation.

Like I said, many features in the Xbox version are not present in this version, though I doubt any sort of dramatic addition on the Xbox will make it worth it for me to shell out another year of XBLG.

Happy Wars PC gets a 7.1 out of 10, and being above 7 gets my recommendation.

Ok, so I absolutely recommend this game, but after playing a lot more ive realized some MAJOR issues that need fixing.

For starters, the enchants are broken as hell. With the ice, electric, and wind enchants you can keep your enemy from being able to attack or use moves completely, which is insanely unfair. They need to be nerfed in power, preferably by making it so its just a low chance to stun, and not every ♥♥♥♥ing hit.

Another thing about the ice enchant, the ice enchant's cast is overpowered as hell. You can easily run and shoot people with it while they're chasing you and they will never get a single hit, and sometimes it affects people that are blocking. You can also jsut spam it and they wont be able to move at all because it freezes them.

Second, the move rush needs to be weakened. You can keep sending people into the air and hit them until they are dead with it, and theres nothing they can do about it. They either need to decrease the power drastically, or implement some sort of invincibility frames system so that you cant be hurt by every hit.

The invincibility frames system should be added because it's extremely easy to gang up on someone and annihilate them without them being able to attack at all. While obviously theres strength in numbers, its such a domination that it seems unfair.

All in all its a great game but these issues need to be resolved.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bugs terrifying bugs that make the game unplayable, if your one of the few people who don't run into the server error bug or the snail speed bug this will probably be a good experience for you.

Happy wars is an open battlefield where the main objective is to break into the enemy's castle and destroy their giant tower. Along the way you'll need to capture towers that act as respawn points. The game is surprisingly varied despite only having 3 classes, upon performing any objective such as healing/buffing an ally, killing an enemy or helping with the construction of turrets you get exp the game has a random mechanic where each game the skills obtained are random which means there wont be any 1 consistent op class mowing through everything.

Despite being a team game the game also does an excellent job of avoiding the problems other multiplayer games have that being of ragers afkers and essentially your teammates messing you over. Its impossible to rage as there isn't actually a chat system in the game outside of predetermined dialogue. Each player is scored and rewarded based off their individual performance and the game is quite geneous with its item drops.

Something similar to an auction house would be nice in the near future to allow players to either buy these premium items or  the cash currency with normal game currency. At the moment I'd recommend you try it out even if it is awfully buggy the game is quite fun and if your lucky and don't run into a game breaking bug you'll have a good time.

Update: after playing much more i've come to the conclusion that the game is p2w. The premium items simply far outclass anything else. The weight mechanic to balance it out is ultimately pointless when after a certain point normal items simply don't weigh enough to hit the cap making it wasted space. It is possible to get premium items from the normal roulette but the odds are extremely low, out of the probably close to a hundred spins i've done i've obtained 2 premium items and this is from using currency earned over 20 hours of play. On top of that there are super premium items" which are impossible to get out side of paying out money.

I would still recommend the game because it is fun and f2p but unless there's new features that allow f2p to obtain those powerful items it's unlikely the game will have any long time merit"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bugs terrifying bugs that make the game unplayable, if your one of the few people who don't run into the server error bug or the snail speed bug this will probably be a good experience for you.

Happy wars is an open battlefield where the main objective is to break into the enemy's castle and destroy their giant tower. Along the way you'll need to capture towers that act as respawn points. The game is surprisingly varied despite only having 3 classes, upon performing any objective such as healing/buffing an ally, killing an enemy or helping with the construction of turrets you get exp the game has a random mechanic where each game the skills obtained are random which means there wont be any 1 consistent op class mowing through everything.

Despite being a team game the game also does an excellent job of avoiding the problems other multiplayer games have that being of ragers afkers and essentially your teammates messing you over. Its impossible to rage as there isn't actually a chat system in the game outside of predetermined dialogue. Each player is scored and rewarded based off their individual performance and the game is quite geneous with its item drops.

Something similar to an auction house would be nice in the near future to allow players to either buy these premium items or  the cash currency with normal game currency. At the moment I'd recommend you try it out even if it is awfully buggy the game is quite fun and if your lucky and don't run into a game breaking bug you'll have a good time.

Update: after playing much more i've come to the conclusion that the game is p2w. The premium items simply far outclass anything else. The weight mechanic to balance it out is ultimately pointless when after a certain point normal items simply don't weigh enough to hit the cap making it wasted space. It is possible to get premium items from the normal roulette but the odds are extremely low, out of the probably close to a hundred spins i've done i've obtained 2 premium items and this is from using currency earned over 20 hours of play. On top of that there are super premium items" which are impossible to get out side of paying out money.

I would still recommend the game because it is fun and f2p but unless there's new features that allow f2p to obtain those powerful items it's unlikely the game will have any long time merit"

reviewText:
Just to note here: Happy Wars does not always make you happy, i'm still depressed most of the time. But you can however buy smiles and such for you character! So i guess that sorta counts.

I do love the game and i do recommend it but i will say some things, and some warnings.

The game is great, its fun, cute and can be addictive.
However for new players it will be hard, good news it you have others you can rely on. I personally like to be a cleric and i heal and revive people as well as buff them. Just play, get happy stars and items, and upgrade. Once you get decent gear and you level it a fair bit you will be able to hold you own, in co-op at least.


If you are wanting to play pvp then you may not do so good a lot of the time, it takes good gear and communication, usually good communication can beat the good gear, teamwork on this game pays off. Many people run into issues with the game itself, such as lag and errors. Ive only ever had lag when i am also using google chrome, so my own fault, but other than that i've never had issues at all.

Its a really fun game, if you are not willing to put up with things as you start out then do not fault the game right away. Other people have already got good things, and the game has been worked on as well, you cannot expect to join in late and do really well.

One thing that i find on this game that makes it unbalanced is the items themselves, they bring out items which are exclusive to happy cards, which you can earn at a very slow pace doing mission mode or by doing good in PvP each month. Now these items are usually better than the ones in the base game, and also they just get better and better. If you get one of these good items then they will most likely bring out a better one. Now you can do really well without spending money, it just takes more time, but don't expect the best items in the game unless you pay money, or are just really lucky.


[Edit] The game is now unplayable for me, I got a new graphics card and always get an error when trying to launch. This is the only game that does such a thing, and I have seen other people talking about having the same issue. I do enjoy this game and would of loved to keep playing despite how pay to win it can be, however since it's now impossible to play, as well having in game issues like bad connection issues with players and also being heavily pay to win I have changed my review to not recommend.

reviewText:
I do love this game honestly, but I can't give recommend it simply because of:

Hardly anyone is online

You are pretty much bound to lose because of hackers and high experienced players

Server error 404 happens quite alot and trust me, I have very decent internet

The main campaign can't be played/finished unless you are a very high level, also each stage you unlock of the campaign is way to short and (for me) it doesn't give me that feel of accomplishment that most games do.

Getting rare items in this game is very unique, I got the king's egg and I can whoop pretty hard with that (considering I'm a level 2 mage, I mainly like to use cleric).

Mashing weapons and other items together to get a stronger weapon is a very cool function.

I do like the customisable characters.

And here is some suggestions:

If you could, prehaps set up a steam shop, I think selling and trading weapons would be a cool feature to add.

Please fix the 404 server error, I lost out on two epic boxes and some coins.

Also maybe make skermish give you XP since hardly anyone is actually online.

Summary: Game has serious balancing issues. Not recommended for new or casual players.
-
* Long loading times, even during peak hours. It can take up to 5 minutes to get into a game. Excessively long loading screens with hard-coded timers on them add to this considerably.
* In most games one or two characters have paid money to get lots of upgrades. I have seen 6v1 battles that went in their favor -- games frequently are won or lost by the presence or absence of such people on either team. Unlocking without paying money takes an insane amount of time; Decent gear will take you over 200 hours to acquire -- with about 15% of that time wasted on forced delays and waiting for matches to start.
* The rank system is broken -- 1 person should not be able to single-handedly beat the entire opposing team. You will see this in almost every match you play.
* The upgrade system is fundamentally broken and designed to suck money out of your wallet. If it were more balanced, I would recommend this game. But as it is now, I cannot recommend this to anyone who doesn't have $50 to throw away.

reviewText:
I used to play this all the time on my Xbox 360, and I loved every second of it...which is why when I saw this port for the PC (with full controller support) I clicked install quicker than my computer was ready to handle. The game is very fluid and the music bouncy and light, the leveling system works well and the campaign progression enticing enough for you to actually try to work through.

However, multiplayer is absolutely pathetic. There are very few players in this game and the quick matches require a certain number of players to start, which is absurdly rare to do. Often, you'll accidentally run into the same people in different lobbies to the point where you'll add them to your friends list just so you can near-guarantee you'll get at least one closer to that benchmark you have to reach. When you do reach that limit, it takes a couple minutes to load up a game and getting in takes even more time, and if you're able to get a full match done without losing anyone (which would thereby forfeit the match for everyone, for god knows what reason) then you realize it's far easier and quicker to just suffer through single player AI skirmishes and work your character up that way, which actually works rather well.

If you're just looking for a good, solid free-to-play game with a SMITE feel to it but with more comical relief, this is your choice. I've been playing this game for maybe a couple years now and I still enjoy it, so I would absolutely recommend it to anyone who just wants to pass some time when they're bored.

8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

More and more MOBA games are getting F2P. Happy Wars are more for players who want to kill players yet having a simplified gameplay. It offers up to a battle between 15-on-15 players, which can get pretty chaotic.

This game only offers three types of classes, the melee-focused Warrior, the healing and support Cleric, and the ranged damage Mage. Each class can learn up to 9 spells, each categories into three segments, the Team Skill, the Offensive, and Defensive. However the skills are randomised everytime you enter a war, allowing you to learn skills as you level up. The maximum level is 5 per war. The level is interchangeable between classes, therefore you no need to re-level whenever you swap to another class.

Climbing up the ladder is fairly easy, but tough once you reach above Level 30. This Level does not coincide with the in-war leveling, but rather your overall ranking in the server. The matchmaking system are pretty good, with both sides balanced out. If the matching takes too long, it will add AI to balance out the remaining slots. AI are pretty dumb as it takes out any players when near, though they can be beneficial at times where you get a sure heal/resurrect.

Getting items are guaranteed as long you level up to level 5 in each war. When in luck, you can get 3 items from the Red Present at the end of the game. Not all items are good. Some will have negative effects on the items, where you need to get it debuffed to remove the effects from the item. While winning the war, you get to earn Happy Stars to spin on the Happy Spinner. Where you gamble your tokens for equipments in a spin, a matter of luck. There's rarely players using P2W for this, even though there's Happy Cards where you get a premium item using cash. Nevertheless Happy Cards are still attainable for F2P players while earning tickets to get the Happy Cards when completing the missions.
